title: #302 Making AI Applications like Greased Lightning with William Falcon, CEO at Lightning AI

rawLines.text: Welcome to dataf framed. This is Rachie.
The AI boom has resulted in an explosion
of new tools for creating yet more AI.
That means that the AI engineers
technology stack has become vastly more
powerful, but also a lot more complex.
It's the modern data stack conundrum all
over again. Today we're talking about
how you can streamline your AI tech
stack in order to develop AI products
faster. Our guest is Will Falcon. He's
the creator of PyTorch Lightning and the
CEO of Lightning AI. PyTorch Lightning
is kind of Ruby on Rails for AI
development and it's one of the hottest
open- source AI frameworks right now. I
want to know why Will created it when
open-source is important in AI
development and how to just stop
threating about tools and get on with
building things. Let's find out how to
develop AI applications like Grease
Lightning. For AI to really take off,
the focus has to be on how to deliver a
business outcome to people, not what
tools to build. Because people don't
necessarily care so much about the
tools, they care about what it lets you
do and and what what the outcomes are of
using those tools. And this is coming
from a tool builder, right? But like we
focus a lot on how can we enable you to
build like an end product. I think that
models should be open source. Like the
thing that's interesting about the
models is not the model itself, but what
you do with the models, right? You don't
regulate technology, you regulate
applications of technology, right?
That's that's kind of where where the
government really should be focused on.
I want to pick up on something that you
said at a meetup I attended. So you said
that you think artificial general
intelligence is going to come out of New
York, not San Francisco. Can you talk me
through why you think that? I think that
in New York you have people from
different backgrounds that are coming at
problems from a different perspective.
You have lawyers, you have doctors, you
have marketing people, etc.
And so I think that that that like
variety in um or breath in viewpoints is
actually what I think will have will
create the next generation of like
foundation sorry like of companies right
and probably to some example um to some
extent like a Harvey or something like
that is like I think a good example of
that where it's like lawyers that are
involved they're doing something very
specific not that there aren't lawyers
in San Francisco but I think in San
Francisco people tend to think more
uniformly about what they build and it
tends to be kind of solving their own
problems and most people are in tech and
so that's kind of the the issue that I
see there. Okay. So there's a difference
just thinking uh about the technology
side of things versus thinking about the
domain side of things and then how the
technology can help the domain. Yeah.
Because I I mean for AI to really take
off the focus has to be on how to
deliver a business outcome to people,
not what tools to build, right? Because
people don't necessarily care so much
about the tools, they care about what it
lets you do and and what what what the
outcomes are of using those tools,
right? And this is coming from a tool
builder, right? But like we focus a lot
on how can we enable you to build like a
an end product. Okay, that's
interesting. Uh do you want to expand on
that? So, how do you get closer to
solving domain problems with lightning?
Yeah, I mean, you know, there's the
there's like a the journey that people
go through from idea to like like a real
product in production and it there's
like a a path, right? And it always
follows something like the ML life
cycle, right? you
like sorry you like label data you
collect well you first collect it you
label it you prepare there's a bunch of
things you do there then you might do
some sort of like you know distributed
uh workflows where you might do
embeddings and then at some point you
end up with like a clean data set I
guess and then now you need to decide am
I going to fine-tune or pre-train a
model am I gonna like what approach am I
going to take there um and sometimes you
might not you might just start with an
API and then use rag anyways there's
like so many decisions along along the
Okay. And then ultimately I think where
most people land is at a P deployment
like something where they're like wow
look at this cool thing that works for
like seven people. But the real answer
is well how do you get something that's
actually live in production and like
really reliable and so on and so um you
know the kind of approach that we have
is really more like we have AI hub which
is like the end of the journey. So like
you don't have to go through that if you
just want something that like is an
agent or an expert or or if you want
like a fully uh fully built rack system
or you want like an actual vertical end
application. Um you know it's funny
because like if you think about what it
actually takes to build so like let's
say something like a Harvey, right? Like
that's an end application, right? So in
a hub you can find those kind of things.
They're like very specialized to a
domain. You just hit them hit one click
deploy and then you got that. But to
build something like that, you need a
workflow usually, which is kind of where
most ML companies are sitting around.
They're like, well, we'll do it with
rag, we'll do it with fine-tuning.
There's like 20 million different
approaches on how to do it. So those
workflows are things you can find in the
help as well. So they kind of give you
that final step. And workflows
themselves are made up of atomic
particles that are models, vector DBs,
etc., which you can also find as a
things on the on the AI hub. Um, and
then if you don't like what's on there,
then we have a whole platform of tools
that you can use to build those things
ultimately, which is studios, right? So,
you want to train a model, go for it.
You want to embed some data, go for it.
Whatever whatever it is, there's like a
suite of tools. So, so that's kind of
the approach we take and and we hope
that we get um our goal is to really
solve that last mile problem for people
and and I think that's where a lot of
the value lies. Wonderful. So basically
you're just saying that a lot of the
hard bit is just getting these things
into production and getting that enduser
application. Is that the biggest
challenge you think is with development?
Well, it's hard once you already decided
what the problem you wanted to solve
was. You took the creativity to decide
how to apply AI in your enterprise. Then
you hire the people who could like do
the work. Then those people decided what
tools to build, what techniques to use.
And yes, if you had all that, then the
hard thing was getting into production.
uh like there was so much hard stuff
before that. Okay. I want to pick up on
something you said. So you're talking
about there are lots of different types
of tooling. So you're saying you've got
the end user applications but for
developers there's different layers of
things. So you got workflow tools, you
got tools for rag, you got tools for
fine-tuning. Uh there's so many
different tools. So I try and follow the
space. I can't keep up. Can you give me
an overview of what all the different
sort of tasks and tools are and what
does a tech stack look like? I I want to
start with the outcome. So the solution.
So for example, if you go to IIHub,
you're going to find something called
the stock research expert, right? Or
sorry, stock research agent. And this
agent literally you can give it a ticker
and it'll go do research on that stock
and give you a report. That's the kind
of thing you build in a in a finan like
a investment bank, right? Okay. So
that's the that's the ultimate
application that in itself is like a
whole company potentially, right? where
like it's like all they do is make that
thing really really good. How did you
get to that? Well, you step one level
down. You take a workflow like a
fine-tuning and deploying workflow that
takes some model, fine-tunes it on that
data and then deploys it and then um
teaches it how to use tools, right? So
that second level is um something that
you can build on the platform with the
tools you have. So we have a way for you
to like create um for example a job that
does fine-tuning and then a way for you
to create a different thing which is
like a deployment that's like a docker
base image you know these are two like
individual things usually where you need
two different products to do it so with
us it's really more like a single
platform that will let you do both at
once right with the same workflow it's
very very straightforward and so so that
gives you the workflows right and then
and then if you wanted to build each
particular piece of that for the
finetuning you actually might need
something like data generation and so
on. And so ultimately for when you're
building those particular um tools,
sorry I I mean it's really confusing
because we're talking about so many
layers here, right? When you're building
those I guess you can call them I don't
know atomic pieces of AI system, you're
going to need a set of tools. So it it
all starts with the studio, right? And
the studio is like a cloud development
environment. So think about it like you
have your VS code on your laptop except
that it's not on your laptop it's on the
cloud and you've got GPUs there and
whatever you could do in your laptop you
can do there and so if you say look I'm
fine tuning a model you're going to need
some GPUs okay so get GPUs takes a few
seconds to get it and now you can clone
your GitHub repo whatever you're going
to do start developing on it testing
iterating swap GPUs if you want to test
a different type of GPU or not and it's
going to persist so it's not going to
lose your progress right so you have to
install anything again or whatever and
then you can do a lot of the iteration
the development side of that right and
then you say okay I'm ready to train the
model and then from there you like
package it up and you submit as a job
and then it goes and trains and then you
can say okay now I need to deploy a
model so you start a separate studio now
and in there you set up your model
checkpoint you set up your server you
debug it you like run the server live
you can hit it because it's on the on
the web right so it's got ports you can
kind of really load test it do all that
stuff and then you ultimately package
that up into a docker container and then
you ship it and gets deployed serverless
as well, right? So really no matter what
the workflow is, the kind of studio is
kind of like the the base foundation for
it usually. Okay, so it's interesting
that there are really discrete tasks
within this AI application development
uh space or within agent development. Uh
so maybe fine-tune is a task, maybe
deployment is a task and you can deal
with them one at a time. So it sounds
like with Lightning Studio you're trying
to have the entire workflow in a single
tool which is quite different to a lot
of other companies where they're focused
on one segment of development. So what's
your motivation for that approach? Well
that was the number one thing we have to
do from day one. So I was when when I
was working when I started doing AI like
more professionally right. So I started
as an undergrad like messing around in
2015 doing research and then when I did
my PhD um I was at med I was at Facebook
AI at the time and you could already
tell there were a lot of tools that were
coming out. There was like a lot of
different things you had different types
of GPUs um you had different like
experiment management stuff um things
that we take for granted today but like
it was like a lot of these different
things. And so when when I I I built
PyTorch Lightning, the first thing I
focused on was how do you get all those
tools to work together nicely in the
training framework, right? So which is
like a very uh it's one level below kind
of where the platform sits. to the
training framework and from that day
that was like 2019 you know I was like
and I had come from like web development
and other stuff and I knew you know you
have an explosion of libraries and I was
like I think one day there's just going
to be a million tools that are happening
and they're going to come come at us you
know fast and I want to build a a
platform that basically is kind of tool
agnostic and like it can pivot like that
very quickly and and the value to a
customer is like when a new tool comes
out that we curate it put it on there
for you and show you how to use it so
you don't have to figure this out and
like we'll also tell you if it's not a
good tool, right? So like to your point,
how do you keep up? I don't think you
do. I think we keep up and we tell you
what's interesting, right? Um and so
that that was really the genesis of the
idea. And then it just took about five
years to figure out how to do that well
because it's a very hard problem, of
course. Okay. So not having to worry
about keeping up with all the latest
tools and having to use them in
different manners. That does seem like
an incredibly powerful thing. So I guess
the advantage of lightning here is just
giving you some sort of consistent
interface to whatever tool you want in
order to develop your AI applications.
Yeah. I mean look it's it's a natural
progression in in things, right? Like
your your phone here, this thing was a
replacement for you carrying a
calculator and a bag and a and like a
separate device for note takingaking and
like a flashlight and and a camera and
all these other things. And so it became
a platform now that has all those things
in it, right? um something like a Slack,
like a Slack was a replacement for a
special tool that you could send images
on and a special tool for texting and a
special tool for sending videos and this
and that. Um, so I think all roads lead
to an end to-end platform for pretty
much any type of new technology and for
AI it's going to happen like you're not
going to you're you're not going to have
specialized tools for training or
serving this there's just point
solutions are band-aids today for the
real product right and so that's kind of
the approach we took and so to us all
those things are plugins ultimately
right like I don't know they're just
built into the thing okay so it's
probably starting fights with a fair few
of the startup companies saying oh All
right, your company's just a plug-in,
but yeah, this is an interesting
approach. All right, so uh we talked a
bit about the tooling side of things and
I'd like to know uh who's going to work
on this. So tell me what sort of talent
you need in order to build um these
applications this sort of general role
of AI engineer. Uh but can one person do
everything or do you need different
people with different skills? Well, with
the right tools you can, right? So I
think I think like you know it's a good
analogy like people like you know car
mechanics maybe or like construction
right like you know could you work on a
car today could you could you like fix
stuff on your in your house like you're
not a specialized maybe you are I don't
know but I'm not like a specialized
mechanic or or um construction builder
but like I'm I guarantee I could go to
Home Depot and find the tools that would
actually help me do something that I
couldn't have done 50 years ago without
being very very specialized cutting wood
or something Right. And so, so I think
that the right tools help you level up
um the people that you work with. And so
our goal is to make it accessible for
anyone in the world to build AI products
ultimately. And I think uh right now um
a huge part of our users are actually
developers who know nothing about AI and
they're coming on here and they're like
great, I don't really care about AI.
Like I I care about building a product
and I don't care how that gets done, but
they're familiar with things like
Kubernetes or whatever else. And so they
can deploy things on the platform. They
can grab a Docker container. they can
put it serverless. Um, and then when
they train a model, you know, it's kind
of a no code experience. So maybe that's
how we do it. It's like for us the no
code stuff is like if you're not an
expert, then go for it. If you're an
expert, we give you the full code
experience and you should be able to
tweak your models and do whatever you
want, right? But if I think if we're
successful, anyone in the world, no
matter what who you are, should be able
to build AI in whatever shape that means
to you. So like AI to my grandparents
means like a a thing that I can chat
with and they should be able to do that.
like what does that look like to you,
right? And uh AI to a PhD means a model
with 24 layers in here in this
particular way and as a transformer with
this type of attention or whatever, then
do it as well, right? Okay. So, you need
different skills for different types of
AI. You also mentioned that a lot of
these people um who are developing AI
things come from a software development
background rather than from a data or
machine learning background. So can you
talk me through what are the most
important skills you need in order to
work with AI to develop things? You
know, I I came from the the PhD
background in AI, right? And like the
the researchers I think are they're
they're get they love the research. They
love to get caught up in like the type
of model and the the way that you
fine-tune and this and that and like you
know to build a products it really makes
marginal difference most of the time
like those kind of decisions, right? um
they're actually been made for you
already in the open source like we've
all done it like we the models are there
they're already set with the standards
you just have to run them so I think
software developers in general are are
best equipped to do this because they're
they're treating this stuff as a tool to
achieve an actual business goal and so
they actually will not get caught up in
like all these details and um and they
actually have pretty pretty solid like
software engineering techniques like how
to how to you know CI/CD workflows etc
etc and that's actually what you mostly
need so I I I don't know I think you
mostly just need to be a fairly
reasonable software engineer who's not
afraid of it, who's who's willing to
like run something and see if it fails.
And no, like be okay with having
something that's working and you don't
know why it's doing what it's doing. And
that's okay. Like, you know, I don't
think anyone here drives a car with
knowing every detail about everything
that happens within that car or like
learning physics to drive a car. You
don't do that today, right? So, there's
no reason to do that to to like hold
yourself to that level. Um, so I think
it's open-mindedness and being okay with
not knowing everything probably is the
the core stuff. Okay. Uh, it's
definitely an important skill to be okay
with not knowing everything because I
mean at this point it's just impossible
to keep up with everything there is. And
I think that for the data framed
audience, a lot of them come from a data
or machine learning background. Are
there any particular software
engineering things that you think are
good to know if you want to work with
AI? We use notebooks for scratch work,
things you're going to throw away,
right? But when you when you're finished
doing the work that you're doing, put it
into Python scripts, like actual Python
scripts with like real entry points and
this and that um so that you can put it
into production meaning you can train
it, you can deploy it etc. We provide a
lot of tools to kind of bridge that gap.
So like if you for example wanted to
deploy a model and that model sitting in
a notebook uh you know like you know why
I think it comes from is because in
legacy data science you could train an
XG boost model on like a CPU notebook
and like three lines of code and now
it's fine. But in AI, you need GPUs, you
need distributed processing, you need
all this stuff that like a a notebook
cannot do because it's l literally a
single Python process. It cannot go and
do multi-process, multi-achine things
because it's like impossible, right? And
so and so that's why we have to break
out of the notebook thing. If you're
doing AI, if you're doing data science,
stick to notebooks. It's great. But so
if you want to grab that model then um
we have something called lit serve for
example where you can grab that model
checkpoint drop it in into this um it's
kind of like pytor lighting but for
serving like a harness I guess and um
and then you have kind of the few lines
of code that you need to do and then the
mlops is kind of handled for you
automatically behind the scenes right it
doesn't have to be a pytor model it can
be an xg boost model can be whatever um
but there are these types of tools that
are helping bridge people out of these
things so I would say just use the right
tools for the right job. If you're
experimenting and if you're doing
analysis, stay in a notebook because you
need the interactiveness of it, the
ability to visualize things 100%. But if
you're going to train or deploy things
for real, then you need to learn Python
without a
notebook. Okay, that's interesting and
probably fighting talk to a lot of data
scientists. So yeah, I think uh there's
definitely some problems with notebooks,
but does that mean there's a gap in the
market for a notebook that does scale to
distributed computing and working with
GPUs or is it just that notebooks are
fundamentally unsolvable and everyone
should switch to writing scripts? No, I
think people have tried. There have been
plenty of products that have tried to do
that. Um I'm not saying never. Maybe
there will be something, but um I think
people can I don't know. They should
really just switch to to writing the
script. Um it it's not even the
distributed part. It's like the out of
order of a notebook. Like how do you how
can you guarantee that this code was
executed in exactly the same order every
time. You can't because people notebooks
they'll do like cell one, cell four,
cell two, cell three and then cell
seven. And that path is what led you to
the model and that's not reproducible,
right? So yeah, uh it sounds like it's a
fundamental problem then with notebook.
So, uh, if users aren't constrained to
executing things in order, I can see how
that's going to cause problems in
production. Don't get me wrong, I use
notebooks, but I use them for the right
thing, which is where order doesn't
matter and it's exploratory work. But
when I'm going to do serious work, I'm
going to use Python scripts, right?
Okay. All right. That seems like a good
thing to know about. Uh, so PyTorch is
very much the dominant player in terms
of frameworks for doing machine learning
research. So why did you feel the need
to create lightning? So what was missing
from the base PyTorch?
Um I equate PyTorch to like
JavaScript. So would you build a website
using JavaScript or would you use
something like React? Right. Okay. So
yeah, it's going to take you a lot
longer to do raw JavaScript everywhere.
Exactly. And like you you're going to re
reinvent the wheel every time. Do you
really need to reinvent state management
for every single website you're going to
build? It's a cool experiment if you've
never done it. It's the same thing in
PyTorch like do you really need to
reinvent the way to save checkpoints the
way to do distributed training the way
to plug into FSTP the way to do multiGPU
training the way to you know log things
manage experiments you know collaborate
like why would you do that every time it
doesn't make sense right um so yeah I
mean that's really why ultimately
because if you're doing anything serious
you're going to need a framework right
it's only the purists who are like ah
let me do this I'm like yeah maybe like
cool story you wrote a JavaScript
website but like you Facebook isn't
written in JavaScript. It's written in
React, right? Google isn't written
JavaScript, it's written in Angular. If
the best people in the world aren't
using JavaScript directly, there's a
reason for it, right? Okay, cool. So,
uh, it seems very sensible having a
framework just to speed things up. So,
are there any particular tasks you think
Lightning makes easier compared to lower
level PyTorch? Um, yeah, I mean,
generally like just the ability to
experiment, right? But I would say the
thing that it shines out the best is
distributed training specifically. So
with lightning, you can write your code
in a way where um it can run on a CPU or
you can run on one GPU or 4 GPUs or a
thousand GPUs without changing anything
about the code and it'll just work out
of the box, right? And you can do it
even on other chips like uh tranium
chips or TPUs or whatever, right? And um
and and I think that's really what's
going to give you the power to kind of
go between laptop cloud, whatever you
want to do as well. Uh, and not to
mention all the all the like best
practices that have been embedded in
there, right? So, so I'll give you
context. So, Lightning has had um
probably close to a thousand
contributors at this point. We did the
math recently. It's something like
400,000 developer hours. So, if you
could, you know, and that's going to get
you stability, correctness, like you
know that the code is not going to have
an issue when you run you you didn't
swap the backward with the way when you
release the the gradients or you didn't
do the the step before the backward or
whatever. all that stuff is sorted out
for you already and like it's very very
robust. So unless you can tell me that
you're going to invest 400,000 hours
into your own codebase to make sure you
have no bugs, then it seems a bit silly
to not leverage the things that people
have built, right? Um so so that those
are interesting stats there. But there
there's so many small optimizations
there as well like the ability to go not
even small I guess to mean that they're
small now, but like eight precision, 8
bit, 4bit, two bit, the ability to um to
just like try test one batch of data and
see what happens. try to overfit one
batch. All these like all these things
you learned during your PhD that like
are embedded in there and they were met
in there by me, by people at Meta, by
people in the PyTorch team, by people at
Facebook AI, by by like a lot of amazing
researchers all over the world who put
the best tricks of the trade into this
thing. So you don't have to learn what
they are anymore, right? That seems very
useful. So uh just building on I guess
the shoulders of giants is the big point
of open source. So can you talk me
through what the relationship is between
the pietorch lightning developers and
the vanilla pietorch developers? Uh I
think it's mostly people at meta right
develop pietorch. Yeah I mean it's it's
over the years it's varied right. So
pietorch is is uh something that came
from meta right. So it's not something
that we developed and um and but you
know when when pietorch was coming out
there were a few of us who were like
very early. So my CTO Luca was actually
much earlier than I was working on
pietorch. Uh like very very early. He
was actually on the PyTorch paper itself
right when it was published um and the
autograph paper before which led to
PyTorch as well. Uh if you guys have
ever read this book deep learning with
PyTorch um he's one of the authors on
there as well. And then another one of
the authors is um Thomas Vman. So Thomas
works with us as well. Thomas wrote
torch script right and so um over the
years we've had people who come from
meta like we we had um for a while we
had um a handful of people from the
pietorch core team as well here working
on on optimizing things and um and you
know there kind of revolving door to
some extent right so some of us go there
some of us they come back and forth and
so on and um and now like serious
organizations have lightning teams
internally so like meta has lightning
team internally who works on their
pyarch lightning like equivalent
internally because At some point they
were using Pyish lighting for like all
of their production stuff and so all
these things have derivatives like
Nvidia has a lighting team like there
there are these companies where they'll
have something internally and we
collaborate with all of them today as
well. Um so it is a a big effort and you
know we support PyTorch beyond just
PyTorch Lightning. So we serve on the
PyTorch Foundation today um and then you
know Luca who I was mentioning our CTO
he's the he's the chair of the PyTorch
Foundation this year as well. So we try
to stay involved in the governance of
how we shape the product um and the
project as well and it's not just us
it's a handful of companies we're doing
that today. Um but you know I I believe
PyTorch is a community project as is
PyTorch lighting today and and we try to
do that for for everyone as well. Um
yeah. Okay. So that seems pretty
fantastic that both these projects got
good collaboration going and you're
working closely with people who are
working on vanilla PyTorch. Now uh both
uh PyTorch and PyTorch Lightning are
open- source projects and it seems like
the large language models whether or not
these should be open source is quite a
divisive issue. So you got the Meta Lama
models are kind of semi-open source they
got open weights and a lot of the
competitors are closed source. So we're
yet to see a completely open model. Uh
do you have a position on how open these
